maml:description.maml:para: Returns a SQL database by name from the specified SQL Server.
If the database name is not specified, then the cmdlet returns all SQL databases for the SQL Server.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The name of the database to be retrieved.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
A database object representing the database to be retrieved.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
A database object representing the database to be retrieved.
The name of the database to be retrieved.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns the database, "Database1", from the Windows Azure SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns information about the SQL Database servers in the current subscription.

The Get-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet retrieves information about SQL Database servers in the current subscription. If a SQL Database server name is specified in the ServerName parameter, it returns an object with information about the specific SQL Database server. Else, it returns information about all the SQL Database servers.

The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve information. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name. If not specified, information about all the SQL Database servers in the current subscription is returned.

The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve information. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name. If not specified, information about all the SQL Database servers in the current subscription is returned.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns information about all of the SQL Database servers in the current subscription.
This command returns information about the “lpqd0zbr8y” server.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.

The Get-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet retrieves firewall rules from the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription. If a firewall rule name is specified in the RuleName parameter, it returns information about the specific firewall rule. Else, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server is listed.
The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve the firewall rules. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
The name of the firewall rule to retrieve. If not specified, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server is listed.
The name of the firewall rule to retrieve. If not specified, information about all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server is listed.
The name of the SQL Database server for which you want to retrieve the firewall rules. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns all the firewall rules in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).
This command returns the specified firewall rule (“myRule”) in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new SQL database.
The New-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet creates a new SQL Server database for the specified the SQL Server connection context.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The name of the new database.
Collation for the newly created SQL database.
The edition for the SQL database. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default value is Web.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
The maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Collation for the newly created SQL database.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The name of the new database.
The edition for the SQL database. Acceptable values are Web and Business. The default value is Web.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
The maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

maml:alert.maml:para: To delete a database that was created by New-AzureSqlDatabase, use the Remove-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a new database with the name, "Database1", on the Windows Azure SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The New-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet creates a new SQL Database server in the current subscription.
Administrator account name for your new SQL Database server.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.

Administrator account password for your new SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Region or location where the new SQL Database server is created. The location determines which datacenter the database will reside in.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Administrator account name for your new SQL Database server.

Administrator account password for your new SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Region or location where the new SQL Database server is created. The location determines which datacenter the database will reside in.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a SQL Database server.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new connection context to the specified SQL Server Management Service.

Using the credentials provided, the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet creates a new connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server. The server may be specified by name, by the fully-qualified name, or by URL.
The name of the SQL Server.
A credential object that provides sufficient authentication for the user to access the service.
The FQDN name for the SQL Server.
A credential object that provides sufficient authentication for the user to access the service.
The URL to access the Windows Azure SQL Database Management Portal for the server.
A credential object that provides sufficient authentication for the user to access the service.
The name of the SQL Server.
A credential object that provides sufficient authentication for the user to access the service.
The FQDN name for the SQL Server.
The URL to access the Windows Azure SQL Database Management Portal for the server.
The name of the SQL Server.

maml:alert.maml:para: If you authenticated without specifying a domain, then if you are using PowerShell 2.0, the Get-Credential cmdlet returns a backslash prepended to the username, for example, "\user" (PowerShell 3.0 does not add the backslash). This backslash is not recognized by the -Credential parameter of the New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext cmdlet. To remove it, use code similar to the following:

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: C:\PS>$cred = Get-Credential C:\PS>$ctx = New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerContext -ServerName "lpqd0zbr8y" -credential $cred C:\PS>$database1 = New-AzureSqlDatabase $ctx -DatabaseName "Database1" -MaxSizeGB 50 -Collation "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example prompts the user for server administrator credentials, connects to the SQL Server, "lpqd0zbr8y", using those credentials, and creates a new database on that server.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The New-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet creates a new firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server.
Use the cmdlet with the IpRange parameter set to allow any IP address within the range specified in the StartIpAddress and EndIpAddress parameters to connect to the SQL Database server.

Use the cmdlet with the AllowAllAzureServices parameter set to allow Windows Azure connections to the SQL Database server. A firewall rule with starting and ending IP addresses equal to 0.0.0.0 will be created. If you do not specify a firewall rule name, a firewall rule with default name “AllowAllAzureServices” will be created.
The name of the SQL Database server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
End value of the IP address range.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
Start value of the IP address range.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The name of the SQL Database server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
Allows Windows Azure connections to the SQL Database server.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
Allows Windows Azure connections to the SQL Database server.
End value of the IP address range.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
New SQL Database firewall rule name.
The name of the SQL Database server where the new firewall rule is created. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Start value of the IP address range.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new firewall rule (“myRule1”) in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) with the specified IP range values.
This command creates a new firewall rule (“myRule2”) in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) to allow Windows Azure connections.
This command creates a new firewall rule with the default firewall rule name (“AllowAllAzureServices”) in the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) to allow Windows Azure connections.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the specified SQL database.
The Remove-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet deletes a SQL Server database at the specified SQL Server connection context.

A database object representing the database to be removed.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
The name of the database to be removed.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
A database object representing the database to be removed.
The name of the database to be removed.
Allows the action to complete without prompting the user for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

maml:alert.maml:para: Because of the severity of the operation, this cmdlet prompts the user for confirmation by default. This can be overridden by using the -Force parameter.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example removes the database "Database1" on the Windows Azure SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.
This example demonstrates the alternative method of passing the database object through the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the specified SQL Database server from the current subscription.
The Remove-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet removes the specified SQL Database server from the current subscription. It also deletes all databases under the specified SQL Database server.
The SQL Database server name to be deleted. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a firewall rule from the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The Remove-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule deletes a firewall rule from the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.
The SQL Database server name from where the firewall rule is to be deleted. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The SQL Database firewall rule name to be deleted.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command deletes a firewall rule (“myRule”) from the specified SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties for the specified SQL database.
The Set-AzureSqlDatabase cmdlet sets properties for the specified SQL database. You can specify the database by name or pass a SQL database object through the pipeline.
The connection context to the specified Windows Azure SQL Database Server.
A database object representing the SQL database to modify.
If specified, the new edition for the SQL database. Acceptable values are Web and Business.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
If specified, the new maximum size for the database in gigabytes. The acceptable values differ based on edition.
Web Edition values: 1 or 5
Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
If specified, the new name of the SQL database.
Returns the input object.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

The name of the SQL database to modify.
If specified, the new edition for the SQL database. Acceptable values are Web and Business.

Business Edition values: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 100, or 150
If specified, the new name of the SQL database.
Returns the input object.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the current size of the database, "Database1", to 20 GB, on the Windows Azure SQL Database Server specified by the connection $ctx.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of the specified SQL Database server in the current subscription.

The Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServer cmdlet updates the properties of the specified SQL Database server. In the current release, you can only update the administrator account password for a SQL Database server.
The name of the SQL Database server to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.

The new Administrator account password for your SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

The new Administrator account password for your SQL Database server. You must specify a strong password. For more information, see Strong Passwords
.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The name of the SQL Database server to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the administrator account password for the SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”) with the new password (“myNewP@ssword”).

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of an existing firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server.
The Set-AzureSqlDatabaseServerFirewallRule cmdlet updates the start IP address and end IP address values of an existing firewall rule in the specified SQL Database server.
Name of the SQL Database server that contains the firewall rule to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
The new end IP address value.
Name of the SQL Database firewall rule to be updated.
The new start IP address value.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.
The new end IP address value.
Allows the action to complete without prompting you for confirmation.
Name of the SQL Database firewall rule to be updated.
Name of the SQL Database server that contains the firewall rule to be updated. Specify only the server name, and not the fully qualified DNS name.
The new start IP address value.
Prompts you for confirmation before executing the command.
Describes what would happen if you executed the command without actually executing the command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command updates the start IP address and end IP address of the firewall rule (“myRule”) in the SQL Database server (“lpqd0zbr8y”).
